title: 461-A
statement: A. Appleman and Toastmantime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutAppleman and Toastman play a game. Initially Appleman gives one group ofnnumbers to the Toastman, then they start to complete the following tasks:Each time Toastman gets a group of numbers, he sums up all the numbers and adds this sum to the score. Then he gives the group to the Appleman.Each time Appleman gets a group consisting of a single number, he throws this group out. Each time Appleman gets a group consisting of more than one number, he splits the group into two non-empty groups (he can do it in any way) and gives each of them to Toastman.After guys complete all the tasks they look at the score value. What is the maximum possible value of score they can get?InputThe first line contains a single integern(1 ≤n≤ 3·105). The second line containsnintegersa1,a2, ...,an(1 ≤ai≤ 106) — the initial group that is given to Toastman.OutputPrint a single integer — the largest possible score.ExamplesInput33 1 5Output26Input110Output10NoteConsider the following situation in the first example. Initially Toastman gets group [3, 1, 5] and adds 9 to the score, then he give the group to Appleman. Appleman splits group [3, 1, 5] into two groups: [3, 5] and [1]. Both of them should be given to Toastman. When Toastman receives group [1], he adds 1 to score and gives the group to Appleman (he will throw it out). When Toastman receives group [3, 5], he adds 8 to the score and gives the group to Appleman. Appleman splits [3, 5] in the only possible way: [5] and [3]. Then he gives both groups to Toastman. When Toastman receives [5], he adds 5 to the score and gives the group to Appleman (he will throws it out). When Toastman receives [3], he adds 3 to the score and gives the group to Appleman (he will throws it out). Finally Toastman have added 9 + 1 + 8 + 5 + 3 = 26 to the score. This is the optimal sequence of actions.

You are given a list of $n$ integers.  Two players take turns with the following rules:

* **Player 1:**
    * Sums all the integers in their current group.
    * Adds the sum to their score.
    * Gives the group to Player 2.
* **Player 2:**
    * If the group has one integer, they throw it away.
    * If the group has more than one integer, they split it into two non-empty groups and give each to Player 1.

What is the maximum possible score Player 1 can achieve?

Two players take turns with a list of numbers. 

* Player 1 adds up all the numbers in their current list and scores that sum.
* Player 2 splits any list with more than one number into two smaller lists and gives them to Player 1.
* Player 1 throws away any list with only one number.

What is the highest possible total score the players can achieve?
